questions.text: Which of the following is the least likely condition to exhibit lesions and changes on the anterior shin? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypothyroidism

 

Hypothyroidism is the least likely among the given conditions to present with specific skin lesions or changes on the anterior shin. Hypothyroidism can lead to generalized skin changes like dryness and edema (notably myxedema), but it is not typically associated with localized lesions on the shin.

 

Myxedema (severe hypothyroidism) is unlikely to present with lesions over shin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis: In Lofgren syndrome which is acute form of sarcoidosis, Erythema nodosum Skin lesions can be seen on shin as seen in the image below.

 

 

Option B. Diabetes: Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum classically seen on anterior surface of legs.

 

 

Necrobiosis lipoidica Diabeticorum

 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism: Pretibial myxoedema is the infiltrative dermopathy (mucin deposition) seen over shin and it can be seen in Grave's disease which is a type of hyperthyroidism.

 

Pretibial myxoedema is depicted in below image:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Page no 59.11, 64.5, 98.6, 149.10

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the clinical condition shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant Melanoma

 

The given image showing a benign proliferation of Nevus (type of melanocytes) in a child points to diagnosis of congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Characteristics of Congenital Melanocytic Nevus

 

  • Seen since birth
  • Black-colored palpable lesion with well-defined borders
  • Surface is rough, hair
  • If > 20cm – giant congenital melanocytic nevus
  • Risk of melanoma is present

 

Congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) can be associated with various complications, some of which include:

 

  1. Risk of Melanoma: Individuals with CMN have an increased risk of developing melanoma, a type of skin cancer. This risk is particularly higher in cases of giant congenital melanocytic nevi (GCMN)
  2. Neurocutaneous Melanosis: CMN can be linked to neurocutaneous melanosis, a condition where melanocytes are found in the central nervous system. This condition can lead to neurological issues and requires careful monitoring and management
  3. Proliferative Nodules: In some cases, CMN may develop proliferative nodules, which are areas of increased pigmentation and growth within the nevus. These nodules should be evaluated by a healthcare professional to rule out malignancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract: This is characterized by clouding of the lens within the eye, leading to a decrease in vision. It is not related to skin lesions such as a congenital melanocytic nevus.

 

Option B: Sturge-Weber Syndrome (SWS) often leads to secondary glaucoma due to vascular malformations affecting eye drainage, with facial involvement increasing the risk.

 

SWS presents clinically as Port wine stain.

 

Port wine stain

 

  • Features: Also known as nevus flammeus, it is a capillary malformation that presents as a flat, pink, red, or purplish mark. It remains unchanged throughout life and can be anywhere on the body but is often seen on the face as shown below in the image.

 

 

Managing SWS-related glaucoma requires a multidisciplinary approach and regular eye exams for early detection and vision preservation.

 

Option D. Basal cell carcinoma: This is the most common form of skin cancer, often associated with long-term sun exposure. It typically appears as a raised, pearly bump and does not usually develop from congenital melanocytic nevi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Congenital melanocytic nevi, especially larger ones, carry an increased risk for the development of malignant melanoma.
  • Monitoring and possibly biopsy of suspicious changes within these nevi are important for early detection of malignant transformation.

 

References: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition page number 75.9 to 75.14 73.2, 73.3

questions.text: Match the Dermatological disorders in Column A with their respective investigations in Column B: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d

 

Explanation:

 

Correct matches:

 

 

1. Tinea: Tinea infections, also known as dermatophytosis, are fungal infections of the skin, hair, or nails. The diagnosis is commonly made by performing a potassium hydroxide (KOH) mount of skin scrapings, which reveals fungal hyphae under a microscope.

 

2. Lepromatous leprosy: This form of leprosy is diagnosed using a slit skin smear, where a sample from the skin lesion is stained and examined for the presence of acid-fast bacilli (Mycobacterium leprae).

 

 

3. Lupus vulgaris: Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis. The diagnosis often involves a biopsy of the lesion, which shows granulomatous inflammation with caseation necrosis and the presence of acid-fast bacilli.

 

4. Allergic dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis is diagnosed using a patch test, where suspected allergens are applied to the skin under occlusive patches to observe for a delayed hypersensitivity reaction.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tinea is diagnosed with a KOH mount, lepromatous leprosy with a slit skin smear, lupus vulgaris with a biopsy, and allergic dermatitis with a patch test.

choices.text: Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

questions.text: A farmer visits you with a foot swelling and multiple discharging sinuses in the lower limb. Microscopic examination of granules from the discharge was performed and is as shown in the image below. Based on this information, what can be concluded about this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both bacteria and fungi can be causative

 

  • The clinical scenario, along with the presence of sulfur granules in the image, suggests a diagnosis of mycetoma. This condition can be caused by either bacteria (Actinomycetoma) or fungi (Eumycetoma).
  • Mycetoma typically occurs following a trauma, and individuals engaged in agricultural work are at higher risk of developing this condition.

 

 

Clinical features (GST):

 

  1. Grains,
  2. Sinuses,
  3. Tumefaction/swelling

 

The below image shows nodular lesions that have broken down to form draining sinuses with purulent discharge.

 

 

 

The discharge contains granules which are microcolonies of the causative organism. It is generally more invasive and can spread via the fascial planes (NOT Lymphatic) to the underlying muscle or bone. Dissemination is rare but can occur in lesions of the head and neck.

 

Treatment:

 

  1. Eumycetoma:
    • Antifungals (Itraconazole)
  2. Actinomycetoma:
    • Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin
    • Modified Welsh regimen: Cotrimoxazole + Amikacin + Rifampicin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. There is lymphocyte accumulation:

While lymphocytes can be present due to the chronic inflammatory nature of mycetoma, their accumulation is not a distinctive feature of this disease.

 

Option C. Undergoes lymphatic spread:

Mycetoma primarily spreads through contiguous tissue invasion rather than lymphatic spread. This is a feature that differentiates it from other infections like lymphatic filariasis.

 

Option D. Involves only superficial tissues:

This is incorrect because mycetoma can involve both superficial and deep structures, including skin, subcutaneous tissue, muscle, and even bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mycetoma can be caused by both bacteria and fungi, and is characterized by the presence of grains in discharging sinuses, often involving deep tissue structures beyond superficial tissues.

 

 

 

Reference –

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition Chapter 32 Page no 32.75

Ananthanarayan & Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology 10th edition Page no 401, 604, 605

Jawetz Melnick & Adelbergs Medical Microbiology 28th edition Page no 689

Harrisons principles of internal medicine 21st edition 1338, 1688

questions.text:
Statement 1: Clinically a patient having flaccid bullae with painful erosions, will show Suprabasal split and inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft on histopathological examination.

 

Statement 2: Row of tombstones appearance is diagnostic of Pemphigus vulgaris (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both the statements are true but 2 is not the conclusion of 1

 

Both statements are true about Pemphigus vulgaris but statement 2 is not explaining 1.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris, a blistering autoimmune skin condition. The condition is characterized by suprabasal acantholysis (a separation of skin cells above the basal cell layer), leading to the formation of flaccid bullae with painful erosions. The "row of tombstones" appearance describes a specific histological feature of Pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: What type of connective tissue is found in the region indicated by the black arrow in the provided image? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dense irregular

 

In the provided image, the black arrow points to a region with a meshwork of collagen fibers. This pattern is characteristic of dense irregular connective tissue, which is identified by its densely packed collagen fibers that are arranged in an irregular, haphazard fashion. This type of connective tissue provides strength and support and allows the skin to resist multidirectional forces. It is typically found in areas that require strength and rigidity, such as the dermis of the skin, which is what is likely being shown in this histological slide.

 

Dermis (precisely Reticular dermis) is made up of dense irregular connective tissue.

 

Irregular connective tissue, is characterized by collagen fibers that are randomly oriented in multiple directions.

 

Irregular connective tissue is of three types: Loose, Dense & Adipose.

 

Dense connective tissue can be found in areas where unsheathed organs are protected and where there is significant mechanical stress.

 

  • This arrangement of fibers provides strength and elasticity in multiple directions, allowing the skin to resist tearing.

 

Function: Provides structural integrity and support for the skin.

 

Dense connective tissue:

 

  • It typically exists in the reticular dermis.
  • Muscle and nerve sheaths made of the superficial connective tissue
  • Adventitia of large vessels
  • Capsules of various organs & glands (e.g.: testis sclera, periosteum, perichondrium)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dense regular connective tissue features collagen fibers that are parallel to each other, conferring tensile strength in one particular direction. It is typically found in tendons and ligaments, where the force is exerted in a single direction as shown in the image below.

 

 

This is not what we see in the image, where the fibers are not arranged in parallel.

 

Irregular and Regular connective tissue

 

 

Option C. Loose regular connective tissue is not a recognized classification.

 

Option D. Loose irregular connective tissue is also not a recognized classification. What is commonly known is loose connective tissue (also termed areolar connective tissue), which has a much looser fiber arrangement and a lot of ground substance, often found beneath epithelial layers, surrounding blood vessels, and nerves. It has a different appearance from what is indicated by the arrow in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The image shows dense irregular connective tissue, which is characterized by a dense network of collagen fibers arranged in an irregular pattern, commonly found in the dermis of the skin, providing strength and the ability to resist multi-directional forces.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.34

Grays Anatomy: The anatomical basis of clinical practice- 42nd edition- page no 40, 41

questions.text: A middle aged Indian male came to Derma OPD with the lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • The lesion in the image presents as a pearly nodule with telangiectatic vessels, which is characteristic of BCC.
  • This type of skin cancer most commonly occurs in sun-exposed areas, such as the face.
  •  The central ulceration and rolled borders are also indicative of BCC.
  • Given the appearance and the location on the face, BCC is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC):

 

  • SCC lesions typically present as scaly, erythematous plaques or nodules, often with a central area of ulceration.

 

 

  • They can also have a rough, sandpaper-like texture.
  • The lesion in the image does not exhibit the typical keratinized or scaly appearance that is suggestive of SCC.

 

Option C. Melanoma:

 

  • Melanoma usually presents with an asymmetrical shape, irregular borders, and multiple colors.

 

 

  • The lesion in the image does not demonstrate these features, making melanoma less likely.

 

Option D. Discoid Lupus Erythematous (DLE):

 

  • DLE often presents as erythematous, scaly plaques with atrophy and dyspigmentation, often affecting the face.

 

 

  • The lesion in the image does not show the scale or the degree of atrophy commonly seen with DLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize Basal Cell Carcinoma by its pearly appearance, telangiectasia, central ulceration, and rolled borders on sun-exposed skin.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 141.1-16, 142.1

Bailey & Loves short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 599, 604-605, 607-609, 611

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with complaints of red spots on her legs that have persisted for several days. She denies any recent trauma or new medications. On examination, there are multiple red and purple areas on her lower legs that do not blanch with pressure. Laboratory evaluation reveals normal platelet counts and no signs of infection. The patient reports having a history of easy bruising and occasional nosebleeds. Which of the following options represents a primary skin lesion seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Purpura

 

Explanation:

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion characterized by red or purple spots that do not blanch under pressure, resulting from the extravasation of red blood cells into the skin or mucous membranes. It is commonly associated with conditions like vasculitis, thrombocytopenia, or vitamin C deficiency. Primary skin lesions are the initial manifestations of a disease process on the skin, indicating an underlying vascular or hematological condition rather than being a result of an external factor or the progression of a skin disorder.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scab: A scab, or crust, is a secondary skin lesion formed by the dried exudate of blood, serum, or pus over an injured or broken skin area. It is not a primary lesion as it develops after skin damage.

 

Option C. Lichenification: Lichenification is a secondary lesion characterized by thickened, leathery skin with pronounced skin lines, resulting from chronic scratching or rubbing. It does not originate directly but rather is a reaction to chronic irritation.

 

Option D. Scar: A scar is a secondary lesion resulting from the healing of skin injuries such as lacerations, burns, or surgery. It represents fibrous tissue that replaces normal skin following injury and is not considered a primary lesion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Purpura is a primary skin lesion that suggests an underlying vascular or coagulation disorder, setting it apart from secondary skin lesions such as crusts, atrophy, and induration, which arise from external factors or the advancement of skin conditions.

questions.text: In the case of a child presenting to the OPD with tense bullae over the torso, and a biopsy of the lesion revealing subepidermal blistering and neutrophil infiltration, what is the preferred drug for treatment? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dapsone

 

  • A diagnosis of linear lgA disease (LIGA), or childhood chronic bullous disease is suggested by the clinical picture of tense blisters with subepidermal separation and neutrophilic infiltration at the basement membrane in a child.
  • This is an autoimmune blistering disorder that can clinically and histologically resemble bullous pemphigoid but is distinguished by linear deposits of IgA at the basement membrane zone.

 

Dapsone:

 

  • The preferred medication to treat LIGA is dapsone.
  • It typically leads to rapid clinical improvement in CBDC
  • Dapsone, which primarily kills bacteria, also has an anti-inflammatory effect by reducing neutrophil enzyme activity.
  • As a result, it is effective in the management of LIGA.
  • Other options such as rituximab, cyclosporine, and azathioprine are reserved for cases that do not respond to dapsone or when dapsone is contraindicated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rituximab: This is a monoclonal antibody that targets CD20 on B-cells and is used in a variety of autoimmune diseases, including those with blistering skin manifestations like pemphigus vulgaris. It is not the first-line therapy for Linear IgA disease.

 

Option C. Cyclosporine: This is an immunosuppressant that inhibits T-cell activation and is used in severe cases of many autoimmune disorders and in transplant patients. It may be used in refractory cases of Linear IgA disease but is not the first choice due to potential side effects, especially in children.

 

Option D. Azathioprine: This immunosuppressive agent is used as a steroid-sparing drug in various autoimmune conditions. It is not the first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease and is considered in cases that are refractory to dapsone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for Linear IgA disease (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood) is dapsone, due to its efficacy in managing conditions with neutrophilic infiltrates.

 

Ref - Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 989,998

choices.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.text: Bindi Leukoderma is caused by which chemical? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP)

 

Bindi leukoderma is caused by para tertiary butylphenol (PTBP) present in adhesive sticker Bindi.

 

  • This is called contact leukoderma or chemical leukoderma in which the chemical increases sensitivity and induces apoptosis of the melanocytes in the area of contact.
  • There is also evidence that azo dyes, by virtue of structural similarity to tyrosine, can directly inhibit methanogenesis by competing with that amino acid for binding with tyrosinase enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. p-phenylenediamine (PPD): Commonly found in hair dyes and can cause allergic reactions and leukoderma but is not the cause of Bindi leukoderma.

 

Option C. Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBEH): Used in rubber and other synthetic materials to cause depigmentation but not in bindi adhesives.

 

Option D. Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3: Azo dyes used in Alta dye, associated with chemical leukoderma but not specifically with bindi leukoderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP), which is a chemical present in high concentrations in the glue of sticker bindis and is known to cause leukoderma through its melanocytotoxic properties.

 

Common chemicals in Indian setup which can Cause chemical leukoderma are:

 

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 128 page no 128.74

Online source: https://europepmc.org/article/pmc/2965911

questions.text: Match the following therapeutic methods used in the management of psoriasis with their possible side effects? (INICET May 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

Correct matches

 

 

PUVA (Psoralen and Ultraviolet A)

 

  • Over 90% of cases of psoriasis are successfully treated with PUVA.
  • Both acute (erythema, blistering) and chronic side effects are associated with it.
  • Use of PUVA for an extended period is linked to non-melanoma skin cancer development (squamous cell and basal cell cancers).

 

Cyclosporine

 

  • Cyclosporine usage is primarily linked to metabolic issues, a possible increased risk of malignancy, and renal impairment (decreased GFR).
  • Due to its nephrotoxic effects, it is now uncommonly used for the maintenance of psoriasis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common therapies for psoriasis with their potential side effects:

 

  • PUVA increases the risk of skin cancer (1-c),
  • Cyclosporine is nephrotoxic (2-b),
  • Methotrexate can act as an abortifacient (3-a), and
  • Acitretin is teratogenic and can cause mucositis (4-d).

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.26-28

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3402

questions.text: A drug used to treat Tinea cruris that is experiencing an increasing development of widespread resistance is? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Terbinafine

 

  • Terbinafine is an antifungal used to treat Tinea cruris ("Jock/Dhobi itch").
  • Tinea cruris is typically caused by the fungus Trichophyton rubrum.
  • Effectiveness of terbinafine is compromised due to increasing resistance, especially in chronic or recurrent infections.
  • Resistance to terbinafine is associated with mutations in the squalene epoxidase gene, diminishing the drug’s efficacy.

 

 

  • Squalene epoxidase is vital for ergosterol synthesis, crucial for the fungal cell membrane.
  • Terbinafine-resistant fungal strains are cross-resistant to other squalene epoxidase inhibitors.

 

NOTE: Despite resistance to terbinafine, these strains remain sensitive to azoles and other antifungal classes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Itraconazole:

 

  • While Itraconazole is effective against dermatophytoses, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Itraconazole inhibits the enzyme cytochrome P450 14α-demethylase, which is necessary for the conversion of lanosterol to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane. This leads to accumulation of toxic intermediates and membrane dysfunction.

 

Option B. Griseofulvin:

 

  • This drug is used for treatment, but there's no specific indication of increasing resistance against it in the context of Tinea cruris.
  • Mechanism of Action: Griseofulvin binds to tubulin, disrupting the microtubule function and thereby inhibiting mitosis in fungal cells. It specifically targets dividing fungal cells.

 

Option D. Voriconazole:

 

  • Mechanism of Action: Similar to Itraconazole, Voriconazole also inhibits the cytochrome P450 enzyme involved in the production of ergosterol for the fungal cell membrane.
  • It has a broad spectrum of antifungal activity. But it is not routinely used for treating superficial fungal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terbinafine is increasingly encountering resistance in the treatment of Tinea cruris, likely due to mutations in the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is the drug's target.

 

Online source:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC148991 HYPERLINK "https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC148991/"/

ncbi.nlm.nih.gov - Management of tinea corporis, tinea cruris, and tinea pedis

ncbi.nlm.nih.gov - Update on terbinafine with a focus on dermatophytoses

[ijdvl.com - III. Antifungal resistance and treatment options https://ijdvl.com/the-unprecedented-epidemic-like-scenario-of-dermatophytosis-in-india-iii-antifungal-resistance-and-treatment-options/

questions.text:
Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to which of the following persons?(INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

 

  1. Sharing the same clothes, towels
  2. Living with a patient with leprosy for > 6 month
  3. Contact of age more than 2 years
  4. Contact for more than 20 hours per week.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to contacts 2, 3 and 4.

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

 

  • Being identified as a contact, i.e., a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours (option 4) or more per week for more than 3 months (option 2) (Exception is blanket approach where no link with an index case needs to be established.)
  • Age: More than 2 years (option 3); if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria.)
  • Consent of the contact obtained. Depending on the country situation, this can be written or a verbal consent. In case of children, consent should be obtained from the parent or guardian, and sometimes an assent from the grown-up children.
  • Sharing the same clothes and towels (Option 1), while a potential route of transmission, is not generally considered a primary criterion for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Exclusion criteria

 

  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of leprosy;
  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of TB or confirmed with TB;
  • Persons with a history of liver or kidney disorders;
  • Pregnancy; SDR can be given after the delivery;
  • Persons who have received rifampicin in the last two years e.g. as treatment of TB, leprosy or as prophylaxis (e.g. contact of another index case);
  • Persons with history of allergy to rifampicin;
  • Refusal to take SDR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy is crucial for contacts who have had significant exposure to an individual with leprosy, particularly those living in the same household or in close contact for extended periods.

 

Rifampicin:

 

  • A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine.
  • Rifampicin has become established as a highly potent bactericidal drug, and it acts by inhibiting the bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Single Dose of Rifampicin (SDR) is used in chemoprophylaxis.
  • Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patient so as to ensure the patient is non-infectious.

 

 

Ref - Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 242

Leprosy/Hansen disease: Contact tracing and post-exposure prophylaxis

https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789290228073 (page 23, 24)

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3051288/

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old patient who has presented with easily rupturing flaccid bulla on the skin and whose biopsy indicates a suprabasal split?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

  • Based on the clinical presentation of bullous lesions and the histologic finding of a suprabasal blister, Pemphigus vulgaris is suspected.
  • This condition involves the production of antibodies, particularly against Desmoglein 3, and sometimes Desmoglein 1. These antibodies are typically of the IgG type. Desmoglein 3 is primarily found in the basal and suprabasal layers of the skin and mucosa.
  • As a result, patients exhibit flaccid bullae on the skin, and mucosal involvement, especially in the oral mucosa, is common.

 

 

  • Ulceration may also occur in other areas such as the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, and larynx. Cutaneous lesions are more frequently observed on the scalp, face, neck, upper chest, and back.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pemphigus Vegetans:

  • Description: Pemphigus vegetans is a variant of pemphigus vulgaris. It features vesicles and bullae that evolve into verrucous (wart-like) lesions, particularly in skin folds.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The primary presentation in the question doesn't describe verrucous or wart-like lesions.

 

Option C. Pemphigus foliaceus:

  • Description: Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of pemphigus but is characterized by more superficial skin blisters than pemphigus vulgaris, and it doesn't typically involve the mucous membranes.
  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The biopsy of pemphigus foliaceus would show a split in the upper epidermis (subcorneal), not a suprabasal split.

 

Option D. Erythema multiforme:

  • Description: Erythema multiforme is an acute, immune-mediated skin condition. It is characterized by target-like lesions and is often triggered by infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus) or certain medications.

 

 

  • Reason for exclusion from the diagnosis: The presentation of erythema multiforme is quite distinct with its target-like lesions, and a biopsy would not reveal a suprabasal split.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by the presence of flaccid bullae that rupture easily and a suprabasal split on biopsy, indicating an autoimmune process causing loss of epidermal cell adhesion.

 

 

Reference: 

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.1-50.10

Online resources:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3884912/

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17619399/

questions.text: A 38-year-old married woman presents with painful blisters on her oral mucosa and genital areas, with a history of similar lesions in the past. A biopsy from the lesion shows a suprabasal split on histopathology. Immunofluorescence microscopy reveals intercellular IgG deposits, as depicted below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Pemphigus vulgaris

 

Explanation:


Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by painful blisters on the skin and mucous membranes, such as the oral and genital areas. The histopathological finding of a suprabasal split and the presence of intercellular IgG deposits in a fishnet pattern on immunofluorescence are hallmark features of pemphigus vulgaris. These findings distinguish it from other blistering diseases.

 

Other options:


Option A. Dermatitis herpetiformis: Typically presents with intensely pruritic vesicles on extensor surfaces, and histopathology would show subepidermal blisters with neutrophils in the dermal papillae, not a suprabasal split.


Option C. Behçet's disease: Usually presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers but does not show the characteristic suprabasal split or IgG deposits seen in pemphigus vulgaris.


Option D. Allergic dermatitis: This condition generally presents with eczematous lesions and would not show the suprabasal split or intercellular IgG deposits characteristic of pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Educational Objective:


Pemphigus vulgaris is identified by painful blisters on mucous membranes, a suprabasal split on histology, and intercellular IgG deposits with a fishnet pattern on immunofluorescence.

questions.text: The 20-year-old young female presented to the OPD with the following forehead lesions. Which of the following methods won't help with the treatment of various stages of this condition? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Topical fluocinolone

 

The patient's age and the presence of comedones on the face are suggestive of acne. With the exception of topical fluocinolone (a topical steroid), all of the aforementioned treatments are effective for treating acne. Regardless of how they are administered (Topical or oral).

 

Topical fluocinolone is a corticosteroid. While it may reduce inflammation, its use is not recommended for acne as it can exacerbate the condition, potentially causing acneiform eruption or steroid acne. Steroids can also lead to skin thinning and other adverse effects when used on the face for extended periods.

 

  • Acne is a chronic inflammatory disease of the pilosebaceous unit. Comedonal lesions are the Earliest lesions of acne,
  • They represent the keratin plugs of the pilosebaceous duct.
  • When the keratin plug is inside the follicle, it is called a closed comedones or whitehead.
  • When the keratin plug is exposed to the environment, it gets oxidized by the air & turns black which is known as open comedones (blackhead).

 

Stages of acne:

 

 

Global alliance algorithm for acne treatment

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Topical benzoyl peroxide:

 

  • This is a commonly used treatment for acne. Its mechanism of action includes reducing Propionibacterium acnes (a bacteria contributing to acne) colonization and producing an oxidizing effect which reduces inflammation.
  • It is effective and is commonly used either alone or in combination with other treatments.

 

Option C. Topical tazarotene:

 

  • Tazarotene is a topical retinoid. Retinoids are vitamin A derivatives that help unclog pores by promoting the shedding of dead skin cells from the surface of the skin and reducing inflammation.
  • They are effective in treating both non-inflammatory and inflammatory acne lesions.

 

Option D. Topical antibiotics:

 

  • These help in reducing the P. acnes bacterial count, which subsequently reduces inflammation.
  • Commonly used topical antibiotics include clindamycin and Nadifloxacin.
  • They may be used alone or in combination with other agents, such as benzoyl peroxide, to reduce bacterial resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Topical fluocinolone, a corticosteroid, can reduce inflammation, but it is not recommended for acne treatment as it can exacerbate the condition.

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Volume 3 Chapter 90 page no 90.1-90.37

questions.text: A patient was treated with steroids for psoriasis. On stopping the treatment, he develops fever, malaise, and lesions as seen in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pustular psoriasis

 

The given clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis.

 

Clinical clues for diagnosis of Pustular psoriasis:

 

  • Pustular Lesions seen after withdrawal of corticosteroids in a psoriasis patient
  • History of fever & malaise
  • Presence of pustules on a circumscribed, fiery red & edematous or scaling plaque

 

Acitretin

 

  • Approved for use in the cutaneous manifestations of psoriasis.
  • It is the DOC for Pustular psoriasis.
  • Female patients should avoid conception for 3 years after receiving acitretin treatment to prevent retinoid induced embryopathy.

 

Acitretin:

 

  • Is associated with photosensitivity.
  • It has half-life of 50-70 hours

 

Absolute contraindications:

 

  • Pregnant women
  • Women who are planning to get pregnant
  • Breast-feeding

 

Relative contraindications:

 

  • Leukopenia
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hypercholesterolemia
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Significant hepatic or renal disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Staphylococcal infection: While staphylococcal infections can cause skin lesions, there's no direct link provided between steroid withdrawal and the onset of such infections. In fact steroid usage would initiate such staphylococcal infections, not withdrawal.

 

Option C. Acute generalized Exanthematous pustulosis (AGEP): AGEP is typically a reaction to medications not due to steroid withdrawal, and its presentation can be similar to pustular psoriasis.

 

Option D. Sub corneal pustulosis dermatosis: Sub corneal pustular dermatosis is also known as Sneddon-Wilkinson disease. It is a rare condition, characterized by pustules that appear in crops over months or years. However there is no direct link between steroid withdrawal and SCPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When a patient with a history of psoriasis presents with fever, malaise, and widespread pustules following the abrupt withdrawal of systemic corticosteroids, consider pustular psoriasis as the probable diagnosis.
  • This condition can be a severe, life-threatening variant of psoriasis that requires prompt medical attention and management.

 

Ref - Goodman Gillman’s he pharmacological basis of therapeutics – 13th edition page no 1276

Online resources - https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/19998529/

Rook’s textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition page no 18.18, 26.22, 35.28, 35.33

questions.text: In a 25-year-old man who visited a primary health center with complaints as shown in the image below, 5 days after engaging in unprotected sexual intercourse. The patient experienced painful ulcers upon palpation, and there was suppurative inguinal lymphadenopathy on the right side. Additionally, the patient has no history of drug allergy. What specific kit will be used for managing this sexually transmitted disease? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kit 3/white

 

The clinical image and findings presented above are consistent with chancroid, a sexually transmitted disease.

 

Chancroid:

 

  • The causative agent responsible for chancroid is Haemophilus ducreyi.
  • The incubation period typically ranges from 3 to 10 days.
  • It is characterized by the presence of painful and deep ulcers, along with tender lymphadenopathy. The recommended kit for managing this condition is Kit 3/White.
  • Initially, a painful papule appears, which later transforms into a painful, non-indurated ulcer with undermined edges, often accompanied by central necrosis.
  • Autoinoculation may lead to the presence of "kissing ulcers."
  • The disease is also associated with painful lymphadenopathy, which can progress to form suppurating sinuses and buboes.
  • When the patient presents with both genital ulcers and inguinal lymphadenopathy (bubo), it is referred to as concomitant genital ulcer as shown below.

 

Chancroid showing Concomitant genital ulcer: Small soft ulcer on the internal surface of the prepuce with painful, fluctuant inguinal adenitis (bubo).

 

NACO KIT 3 / White color KIT

 

Kit 3/white consists of:

 

  1. Tablet Azithromycin 1gm single dose, which is used for the treatment of chancroid.
  2. Injection Benzathine Penicillin 2.4 Million IU deep IM stat, which is used for syphilis.

 

 

  • Concomitant genital ulcer is seen associated with Chancroid, but absent in LGV.
  • First line treatment for Chancroid is azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose or ceftriaxone 250 mg IM as a single dose.

 

The second-line options for chancroid are as follows:

 

  • Ciprofloxacin 500 mg orally twice a day for 3 days (OR)
  • Erythromycin base 500 mg orally four times a day for 7 days

 

Differentiating features between Herpes genitalis & Chancroid:

 

 

Other KITs:

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When managing a patient presenting with painful genital ulcers and suppurative lymphadenopathy (Bubo), the primary consideration is to treat for chancroid which is a STI, typically with a kit containing appropriate antibiotics.

 

Kit 3/white consists of:

 

  1. Tablet Azithromycin, which is used for the treatment of chancroid.
  2. Injection Benzathine Penicillin, which is used for syphilis.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II - 9th Edition, Chapter 30 Page no 30.21

questions.text: A rose gardener with a history of thorn prick presents with the following lesions. What is the possible causative agent? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sporothrix schenckii

 

Diagnosis from the given findings is Sporotrichosis.

 

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

 

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear nodulo-ulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in:

 

  • Fish tank/Swimming pool granuloma
  • Lupus vulgaris.

 

The given image shows the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology: Asteroid bodies are seen as shown in the image below.

 

 

Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes:

 

  • While Streptococcus pyogenes can cause skin infections, it is not typically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening.
  • This bacterium is more commonly linked with pharyngitis, scarlet fever, and rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Strongyloides stercoralis:

 

  • This is an intestinal nematode and is not associated with skin lesions from thorn pricks.
  • It primarily causes gastrointestinal symptoms and can cause systemic disease in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus:

 

  • This bacterium can indeed cause skin infections, but the scenario described is not its classic presentation.
  • Staphylococcus aureus can take advantage of wounds to cause infection, but it is not specifically associated with thorn pricks or rose gardening

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of thorn prick, especially a gardener, presenting with nodular lesions along lymphatic channels, the most likely causative agent is Sporothrix schenckii, responsible for sporotrichosis, a fungal infection commonly associated with gardening activities.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - Volume II-9th Edition, Chapter 32 Page no 32.71

Illustrated synopsis of dermatology & sexually transmitted diseases page no 297

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine, 21st edition Page no 1542

questions.text: Identify the finding associated with the condition shown in the image below which is characterized by development of morphologically similar lesions along the lines of trauma:  (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Isomorphic phenomenon

 

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin.
  • The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.

 

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

 

Darier’s disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

 

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Gottron's papule seen associated with Dermatomyositis.

 

Option B. Nikolsky Sign

 

Description: Positive when the superficial epidermis moves laterally with slight rubbing or pressure, leading to the separation of the epidermis from the underlying dermis as shown in the below image.

 

 

 

Option D: Meyerson phenomenon is a melanocytic nevus that has developed an eczematous ring around it as seen in the image below.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isomorphic phenomenon (Koebner phenomenon) as the appearance of skin lesions similar to a primary disease along areas of skin trauma, which is important for diagnosis and management in dermatology.

 

References:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 123.2

choices.text: Oral hairy Leukoplakia

questions.text: An immunocompromised patient presents with the following lesion on the lateral aspect of the tongue as shown in the image below. This white membrane was not scrapeable with a gauze piece. What is the diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oral Hairy Leucoplakia

 

Option A:

 

Oral Hairy Leukoplakia:

 

  • This condition is characterized by a white, corrugated, "hairy" plaque typically found on the lateral borders of the tongue.
  • It is commonly seen in immunocompromised individuals, especially those with HIV.
  • The white membrane is not scrapeable, which helps to distinguish it from candidiasis.
  • The presence of this lesion in an immunocompromised patient that is non-scrapeable strongly indicates Oral Hairy Leukoplakia, which is associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus:

 

  • This condition usually presents as white, lace-like patterns (Wickham's striae) as shown in the image below, on the buccal mucosa, tongue, and other oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It can sometimes have erosive, painful areas, but it does not have the "hairy" appearance typical of Oral Hairy Leukoplakia.

 

Option C. Lichen Sclerosus:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that typically affects the anogenital area, not the oral mucosa.

 

 

  • It is characterized by white patches that can lead to scarring, but it does not occur on the tongue.

 

Option D. Candidiasis:

 

  • Also known as oral thrush, candidiasis presents with white patches that typically can be scraped off to reveal a red, bleeding surface underneath. The fact that the lesion in the image is not scrapeable makes candidiasis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diagnose Oral Hairy Leukoplakia by its characteristic non-scrapeable, white, hairy appearance on the lateral aspect of the tongue, especially in immunocompromised patients.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 25.33
